the placement of the premises on the National Register of Historic Places, and/
or the designation of the premises as a landmark, and/or the date of
construction of the building to which the sign is affixed.
(Ord. 29-2002.  Passed 11-21-02; Ord. 5-2003.  Passed 2-6-03; Ord. 30-2005. 
Passed 10-6-05.)
826.06  SIGNS PERMITTED IN ALL SIGN DISTRICTS.
   The following signs are permitted throughout the City subject to the
regulations set forth below and any applicable district regulations. They are
not advertising signs for the purpose of calculating total message area, but
must conform to all other regulations of this chapter, and do require a permit.
   (a)   Construction signs, provided the following requirements are met:
      (1)   One construction sign up to 96 square feet in message area shall be
permitted at each permanent public access to a residential, office, commercial
or industrial building or development which is actively under construction.
      (2)   Construction signs shall be permitted only during the period
beginning with actual construction and ending with the completion of the
building or development.
      (3)   Construction signs shall meet the setback requirements of the
district wherein located as if the sign were a building.
      (4)   Construction signs may state the name and type of development,
names of architects and contractors and their addresses, and drawings of the
development under construction; however, no prices for sale, lease or rent
shall be stated in a construction sign.
   (b)   Signs on water towers in excess of 45 feet in height, stating only the
name of the company utilizing the water tower, and not exceeding 200 square
feet in message area. The message area shall be entirely within the upper one-
third of the tower's height. Signs on water towers less than 45 feet in height
shall be subject to sign district regulations as if they were not on a water
tower. Water towers shall not be considered double-sided signs.
   (c)   Identification signs for industrial, commercial or residential
developments, which include more than 1 owner or tenant. Permit requests for
identification signs shall be granted only if all the following requirements
are met:
      (1)   Identification signs shall be limited to major development
entrances and minor entrances within developments. Each sign shall not exceed
40 square feet in message area on thoroughfares where the speed limit is less
than 40 mph or 60 square feet on thoroughfares where the speed limit is 40 mph
or greater.
      (2)   Identification signs shall not exceed 8 feet in height in
residential sign districts and 10 feet in height in commercial and industrial
sign districts.
      (3)   Identification signs have no required minimum setback.
      (4)   The proposed identification sign shall be designed for aesthetic
compatibility with the surrounding neighborhood.
      (5)   The number of identification signs related to the development shall
be functionally justified and compatible with the design, site and character of
the development.
   (d)   Telephone signs.
   (e)   Awning signs, provided:
      (1)   One awning sign shall be permitted on a parcel;
      (2)   The awning shall not pivot, but shall be permanently affixed to the
building, non- pivoting and stationary;
      (3)   The awning may project any distance from the building but shall not
project to within 15 feet of the public right-of-way, with the following
exception: an awning that projects no greater than 4 feet from the building may
project to no nearer than 5 feet of the public right-of-way;
      (4)   The awning shall maintain a minimum clear vertical clearance of 8
feet at its lowest point;
      (5)   Total sign message area shall not exceed 25% of the total square
footage of said awning.
(Ord. 29-2002.  Passed 11-21-02; Ord. 35-2003. Passed 10-2-03.)
826.07  SIGNS PROHIBITED IN ALL SIGN DISTRICTS.
   The following types of signs are prohibited in all sign districts unless
specifically excepted below or expressly permitted within the applicable
district regulations:
   (a)   Hazardous signs.
   (b)   Signs imitating or resembling official traffic or governmental signs
or signals.
   (c)   Portable signs, except when permitted as temporary signs, regulated
under Section
826.201.
   (d)   Vehicular signs.
   (e)   Animated signs, except those permitted on ground signs, regulated
under Sections
826.09(d),
826.10(d), and
826.11(e), or as temporary signs, regulated under Section
826.201.
   (f)   Signs placed on or over any public right-of-way or on public lands,
including but not limited to signs attached to trees, utility poles, public
benches or street lights, unless expressly permitted by this chapter or by
written permission of the City Manager, authorized by Council. Wall signs shall
not be deemed to extend over a public right-of- way by virtue of their
thickness or other extension beyond the surface of the building, provided that
such thickness or extension does not exceed 6 inches from the face of the
building to the face of the sign.
   (g)   Portable signs.
   (h)   Wall signs extending above or beyond the surface to which they are
attached.
   (i)   Multi-faced signs.
   (j)   Double-faced signs having faces which are not parallel and congruent
or which are more than 6 inches apart.
   (k)   Roof signs.
   (l)   Projecting signs, except as allowed in Sections
826.06(e),
826.10(f) and
826.11(f).
   (m)   Soffit signs which extend beyond the fascia.
   (n)   Signs utilizing Day-Glo, fluorescent or neon colors.
   (o)   Signs painted directly on a wall or other surface of a building.
   (p)   Any functional or structural sign type or classification which is not
clearly identified, defined and permitted by this chapter.
(Ord. 29-2002.  Passed 11-21-02;  Ord. 5-2003.  Passed 2-6-03; Ord. 35-2003.
Passed 10-2-03.)
826.08  SIGN DISTRICTS ESTABLISHED.
   (a)   The Industrial Sign Districts include all parcels within areas which
are currently or subsequently zoned to allow industrial land uses such as
manufacturing, processing, and warehousing, and which are actively used for
such industrial land uses. Also included are all parcels upon which such
industrial land uses are lawfully conducted, regardless of zoning.
   (b)   The Commercial Sign Districts include all parcels within areas which
are currently or subsequently zoned for retail or wholesale commerce in goods
or services as the most intensive use, and which are actively used for such
commerce. Also included are all parcels upon which such retail or wholesale
commerce is lawfully conducted, regardless of zoning.
   (c)   The Architectural Sign Districts include all parcels within areas
which are currently or subsequently designated by official action of the City
Council as architectural or historic districts, and all parcels outside such
areas which are presently or subsequently listed on the National Register of
Historic Places by the U.S. Department of Interior or designated as landmarks
by the City Council.
   (d)   The Residential Sign Districts include all parcels within areas which
are currently or subsequently zoned to allow residential habitation as the most
intensive use, and all parcels which are used exclusively for residential
habitation, regardless of zoning.
(Ord. 29-2002.  Passed 11-21-02.)
826.09  SIGNS PERMITTED IN INDUSTRIAL SIGN DISTRICTS.
   (a)   Only the following functional classes of signs are permitted on a
parcel, subject to the limitations stated below and elsewhere in this chapter:
      (1)   Advertising signs.
      (2)   Real estate signs. The sum of the message areas of all real estate
signs shall not exceed 32 square feet for each side of the parcel with street
frontage.
      (3)   Real estate open house signs.
      (4)   New business signs.
      (5)   Vending machine signs.
      (6)   Signs listed under Sections
826.04 through
826.06.
   (b)   Advertising Signs.  Advertising signs shall meet the following
requirements:
      (1)   Allowable message area.  The allowable message area is calculated
as follows:
         A.   Where the principal building has a floor area of 10,000 square
feet or less, 15 square feet for each 1,000 square feet or fraction thereof of
floor area of the principal building.
         B.   Where the principal building is over 10,000 square feet, 150
square feet for the first 10,000 square feet, plus 5 square feet for each
additional 1,000 square feet of floor area over the first 10,000 square feet.
         C.   Where the name of the premises, such as that of a multiple
occupancy industrial building, is distinct from that of any occupant,
additional allowable message area may be used for the sole purpose of stating
the name of the premises. The additional allowable message area is 50 square
feet for a development of 1 acre or less, plus 20 square feet for each
additional acre or fraction thereof.
   (c)   Limitations on Wall Signs. Only one wall sign per occupant space shall
be permitted, unless the parcel has no ground sign. In that event, one wall
sign in addition to those otherwise permitted on the parcel shall be allowed,
provided that all advertising signs on the parcel remain within the allowable
message area. Wall signs shall be separated by a minimum of 5 feet. No wall
sign may exceed 500 square feet in message area.
   (d)   Limitations on Ground Signs.  One ground sign is permitted on each
side of the parcel with street frontage, not to exceed 2 ground signs per
parcel.
      (1)   Ground signs shall maintain a minimum setback of 25 feet, and shall
not exceed 8 feet in height.
      (2)   The maximum message area at the 25-foot setback is 100 square
feet.  Signs larger than 100 square feet will be required to maintain an
additional 1-foot setback for every 8 square feet, or fraction thereof, that
the message area is increased. No ground sign may exceed 300 square feet in
message area.
      (3)   Ground signs may include a digital display message area, as part of
the overall message area calculation. A digital display may extend the entire
length of the ground sign. However, it shall not exceed 12 inches in height and
shall only include one line of message. A digital display message shall not be
situated to create a traffic hazard, either by the location of its placement on
the sign, the height of the digital message, the color of the display or
background, or the manner in which it is displayed (e.g., flashing, scrolling,
etc.)
   (e)   Window Signs.  Window signs shall not obscure more than 10% of the
window area facing street frontage of any building on the parcel.
   (f)   Reader Board Signs. A reader board sign shall be permitted provided:
      (1)   One reader board shall be permitted per frontage;
      (2)   The background color shall be white;
      (3)   It shall not be installed as a stand-alone sign but, rather, shall
be installed below an existing primary pole or ground sign or below a new
ground sign;
      (4)   Its width shall not exceed the width of the primary sign;
      (5)   Its area shall not exceed 50% of the area of the primary sign; and
      (6)   Reader boards shall be subject to all other regulations, including,
but not limited to, its area being included in the calculation of total
allowable signage.
(Ord. 29-2002.  Passed 11-21-02; Ord. 35-2003. Passed 10-2-03; Ord. 42-2003.
Passed 11-20-03.)
826.10  SIGNS PERMITTED IN COMMERCIAL SIGN DISTRICTS.
   (a)   Only the following functional classes of signs are permitted on a
parcel, subject to the limitations stated below and elsewhere in this chapter:
      (1)   Advertising signs.
      (2)   Real estate signs. The sum of the message areas of all real estate
signs shall not exceed 32 square feet for each street frontage.
      (3)   Real estate open house signs.
      (4)   New business signs.
      (5)   Street numbers.
      (6)   Political signs.
      (7)   Vending machine signs.
      (8)   Signs listed under Sections
826.04 through
826.06.
   (b)   Advertising Signs.  Advertising signs in commercial districts shall
meet the following requirements for allowable message area, with the exception
of ground signs, which shall follow the requirements of division (d) of this
section.  The allowable message area shall be calculated as follows:
      (1)   One square foot for each linear foot of building frontal width of
an occupant space facing a street with a speed limit of less than 40 mph; or
      (2)   One and one-half square feet for each linear foot of building
frontal width of an occupant space facing a street with a speed limit of  40
mph or more; or
      (3)   For a building located on a corner property, facing two streets,
the allowable message area shall be the sum of the allowance for each frontage.
         SAMPLE CALCULATION:
   One side of a building, 40 feet wide, faces a street with a speed limit of
45 mph:      60 square feet
   Another side of the building, 30 feet wide, faces a street with a speed
limit of 35 mph:   30 square feet
         Total Allowable Message Area :                   90 square feet
   (c)   Limitations on Wall Signs.  One primary and one secondary wall sign
per occupant space shall be permitted.  The primary wall sign shall not exceed
the message areas below.  The secondary wall sign shall be no greater than 50%
of the size of the primary wall sign. The secondary wall sign shall be erected
on a side or rear elevation only.  Where the occupant has building frontal
width facing more than one street, the occupant shall be permitted one primary
wall sign facing each street.  Wall signs shall be separated by a minimum of 5
feet.
      (1)   If the frontage has a ground sign:
 
Setback from Curb Maximum Message Area
0 to 100 feet     50 square feet
101 to 250 feet   65 square feet
251 to 350 feet   75 square feet
351 feet and over 100 square feet
 
      (2)   If the frontage has no ground sign:
 
Setback from Curb Maximum Message Area
0 to 100 feet     100 square feet
101 to 250 feet   115 square feet
251 to 350 feet   125 square feet
351 feet and over 150 square feet
 
   (d)   Limitations on Ground Signs. Ground signs shall maintain a minimum
setback of 15 feet. Only 1 ground sign is permitted on each side of the parcel
with street frontage. No ground sign shall exceed 50 square feet in message
area or 8 feet in height.  For  buildings which may legally contain 15 or more
tenants, as delineated in approved construction drawings, no ground sign shall
exceed 180 square feet in message area or 18 feet in height.
   (e)   Window Signs.  Window signs shall not obscure more than 50% of the
transparent window area facing street frontage of any building on the parcel.
   (f)   Easel Signs. Easel signs shall be allowed only in the Downtown
Commercial District, as designated by the Official Zoning Map of Trenton, Ohio,
on parcel numbers R8000-009-000-092, R8000-008-000-035, and R8000-006-000-133;
and, to advertise food specials on a property legally being used as an "Eating
Place, Drive-In," "Eating Place No. 1," or "Eating Place No. 2," as defined in
Section 1242.01 of these Codified Ordinances. Use of easel signs shall further
be subject to the following:
      (1)   Only one easel sign shall be allowed per property;
      (2)   The message area of each face shall not exceed 9 square feet;
      (3)   The height of the sign shall not exceed 4 feet;
      (4)   No part of the sign shall be lighted;
      (5)   Decorations may be attached to the sign, including, but not limited
to, balloons, flags, banners, or streamers provided, however, that no
decorations shall be allowed to impede the flow of pedestrian or vehicular
traffic or otherwise cause a distraction, as determined by the Safety Director
in consultation with the Police Chief. No decorations shall extend more than 2
feet above the top of the sign;
      (6)   Sign construction shall be decorative in nature, of metal, hardwood
or like construction but shall not be constructed of pliable wood, or paper,
that is not rated for exterior use. Exposed framing materials not painted or
otherwise covered shall not be allowed;
      (7)   The message area of the sign may be of a permanent nature, able to
be readily changed, or a combination of both. Acceptable media for readily
changeable message area shall be limited to exterior-rated ink markers (aka,
"magic markers") or calcium carbonate (aka, "chalk"). No changeable letters or
numbers shall be allowed, including, but not limited to, those that are used on
portable signage;
      (8)   While the sign may rest on the public right-of-way, it shall not be
greater than 25 feet from the business structure, nor shall it impede
pedestrian or vehicular traffic or visibility in any way, nor shall it be
placed in the public thoroughfare (street, road, avenue, etc.);
      (9)   The sign shall only be displayed during the operating hours of the
business. The sign shall be removed to the interior of the building at all
other times and shall not be visible from the public thoroughfare.
   (g)   Limitation on Projecting Signs.
      (1)   Projecting signs shall be allowed only in the Downtown Commercial
Zoning District, as defined by the Official Zoning Map of the City, as may be
amended from time to time by City Council.
      (2)   Projecting signs shall maintain a minimum clear vertical clearance
of 8 feet at its lowest point but shall not extend above the surface to which
it is attached.
      (3)   Projecting signs shall not exceed 9 square feet in size nor shall
one side exceed 3 feet in length or width.
      (4)   Projecting signs shall not overhang the City right-of-way except
over a pedestrian sidewalk, and then only to a maximum of 4 feet from the
building.
   (h)   Reader Boards. A reader board shall be permitted in all commercial
districts except the Downtown Commercial District (C-D District) provided:
      (1)   One reader board shall be permitted per frontage;
      (2)   The background color shall be white;
      (3)   It shall not be installed as a stand-alone sign but, rather, shall
be installed below an existing primary pole or ground sign or below a new
ground sign;
      (4)   Its width shall not exceed the width of the primary sign;
      (5)   Its area shall not exceed 50% of the area of the primary sign; and
      (6)   Reader boards shall be subject to all other regulations, including,
but not limited to, its area being included in the calculation of total
allowable signage.
(Ord. 29-2002.  Passed 11-21-02; Ord. 33-2003. Passed 9-24-03; Ord. 35-2003.
Passed 10-2-03; Ord. 32-2004. Passed 12-2-04; Ord. 42-2003. Passed 11-20-03;
Ord. 02-2006.  Passed 1-19-06; Ord. 21-2006.  Passed 9-7-06; Ord. 27-2006. 
Passed 11-2-06.)
826.11  SIGNS PERMITTED IN ARCHITECTURAL SIGN DISTRICTS.
   (a)   Only the following functional classes of signs are permitted on a
parcel, subject to the regulations stated below and elsewhere in this chapter:
      (1)   Advertising signs.
      (2)   Real estate signs not exceeding 9 square feet in message area each,
limited to one sign for each street frontage.
      (3)   New business signs.
      (4)   Domestic advertising signs.
      (5)   One business hours sign.
      (6)   One nameplate.
      (7)   Signs listed under Sections
826.04 through
826.06.
   (b)   Advertising Signs.  Advertising signs in architectural sign districts
shall relate only to the business(es) being conducted on the parcel on which
the sign is located.
   (c)   Message Area.  The allowable message area is 20 square feet.
   (d)   Limitations on Wall Signs.
      (1)   Wall signs shall not be painted directly on a building or wall.
      (2)   Wall signs shall not exceed one-half the height of the surface to
which they are attached, or 8 feet, whichever is greater.
      (3)   Wall signs shall not extend more than 4 inches beyond the surface
to which they are attached.
   (e)   Limitations on Ground Signs.
      (1)   Only one ground sign is permitted on a parcel.
      (2)   The maximum sign height is 8 feet.
      (3)   A minimum setback of 15 feet is required.
      (4)   Ground signs may include a digital display message area, as part of
the overall message area calculation. A digital display may extend the entire
length of the ground sign. However, it shall not exceed 12 inches in height and
shall only include one line of message. A digital display message shall not be
situated to create a traffic hazard, either by the location of its placement on
the sign, the height of the digital message, the color of the display or
background, or the manner in which it is displayed (e.g., flashing, scrolling,
etc.).
   (f)   Limitations on Projecting Signs.
      (1)   Projecting signs shall not exceed a sign height of 12 feet.
      (2)   Projecting signs shall not overhang the City right-of-way except
over a pedestrian sidewalk, and then only to a maximum of 3 feet.
   (g)   Window Signs.  Window signs may not obstruct more than 10% of the
aggregate transparent window area facing street frontage of any building on the
parcel.
   (h)   Illumination.  Signs may not be internally illuminated.
   (i)   Architectural Review. 
      (1)   All permanent signs shall be subject to architectural review by the
City Planning Commission. In determining whether or not to grant approval, the
Commission shall consider the following:
         A.   Is the sign appropriate in scale to the building with which it is
associated?
         B.   Is the sign appropriate in design to the architectural style or
period of the building with which it is associated?
         C.   Are the colors selected for the sign compatible with the building
with which it is associated?
         D.   Is the sign located so as to reasonably minimize adverse
aesthetic effects on the architectural design of the building with which it is
associated?
      (2)   Application for architectural review by the Planning Commission
shall be made to the City simultaneously with, or prior to the application for
the sign permit. Applications shall be on the form prescribed by the City,
accompanied by a dimensioned scale drawing or dimensioned photograph of the
sign indicating its typographic style, graphics, colors, supporting structure
and other visual detail. Such application shall bear no fee.
(Ord. 29-2002.  Passed 11-21-02; Ord. 35-2003. Passed 10-2-03.)
826.12  SIGNS PERMITTED IN RESIDENTIAL SIGN DISTRICTS.
   Only the following functional classes of signs are permitted on a parcel,
subject to the regulations stated below and elsewhere in this chapter:
   (a)   One home occupation sign, provided that such sign is no larger than 2
square feet in message area. Exception: home occupation signs identifying a
bed-and-breakfast shall be no larger than 4 square feet in message area.
   (b)   Real estate signs not exceeding 9 square feet in total message area.
   (c)   Real estate open house signs.
   (d)   Domestic advertising signs.
   (e)   Street numbers.
   (f)   One nameplate.
   (g)   Signs listed under Sections
826.04 through
826.06.
(Ord. 29-2002.  Passed 11-21-02.)
826.13  INTERSTATE HIGHWAY SIGNS.
   In addition to all other signs permitted by this chapter, and
notwithstanding limitations as to allowable message area, interstate highway
signs shall be permitted, subject to the following regulations.
   (a)   Interstate highway signs shall be permitted only on parcels which are
either entirely or partially within 750 feet from an interstate highway.
   (b)   Each interstate highway sign shall be located and oriented so that its
message area is clearly and continuously visible from at least 1 direction of
travel on the interstate highway for at least 5 seconds before the viewing
motorist reaches an off ramp while the motorist is traveling at the maximum
speed permitted.
   (c)   No more than 1 interstate highway sign may be erected on a single
parcel. Interstate highway signs may only be located on the parcel which the
business use being advertised actually occupies.
   (d)   Interstate highway signs shall not have a sign height in excess of 60
feet without a variance. The Board of Zoning Appeals may approve a variance
allowing a greater sign height only if all the following conditions are
present:
      (1)   The 60-foot height limitation prevents compliance with division (b)
of this section due to 1 or more visual obstructions. For the purpose of this
division (d), other signs shall not be regarded as visual obstructions.
      (2)   The effect of the obstructions cannot be avoided by locating the
sign elsewhere on the same parcel for which the sign is proposed.
      (3)   The height granted by the variance is no more than 10 feet greater
than necessary to satisfy the visibility requirement of division (b) of this
section.
      (4)   The location of the sign will not prevent the continuing compliance
of a previously existing sign with the visibility requirement of division (b)
of this section.
   (e)   Each application for a permit for an interstate highway sign shall be
accompanied by the certification of an Ohio-registered architect or engineer
that the proposed sign meets all applicable structural safety standards.
   (f)   The message area of an interstate highway sign shall not exceed 120
square feet. This message area shall not be included in the calculation of
total message area.
   (g)   Interstate highway signs with an overall height greater than 25 feet
shall be supported by a single pole or standard. All poles or standards used to
support interstate highway signs shall be white or silver. Wood poles or
standards shall not be permitted.
   (h)   Interstate highway signs shall be set back a distance of at least 8
feet from all public rights-of-way, and shall not be permitted at any location
where vehicular sight distances are adversely affected.
   (i)   Interstate highway signs shall comply with applicable State and
Federal laws.
(Ord. 29-2002.  Passed 11-21-02.)
826.14  SIGNS ON UNDEVELOPED PROPERTY.
   No sign shall be located on undeveloped property within the City, except
those expressly permitted by Sections
826.04 through
826.06.  A sign to promote an establishment shall be located on the same parcel
as the establishment itself, except that an establishment may erect a sign on a
vacant property that is adjacent to the property on which the establishment is
located, provided said vacant property is owned by the establishment.
(Ord. 29-2002.  Passed 11-21-02; Ord. 27-2006.  Passed 11-2-06.)
826.15  SIGNS OVER A STREET, ALLEY OR DRIVEWAY.
   No sign projecting or hanging over a public or private street, alley or
driveway shall, at its point, be less than 14 feet above the pavement surface.
(Ord. 29-2002.  Passed 11-21-02.)
826.16  SIGNS OVER A PEDESTRIAN WALKWAY.
   No sign projecting or suspended over a public or private pedestrian walkway
shall, at its lowest point, be less than 8 feet above the walkway.
(Ord. 29-2002.  Passed 11-21-02.)
826.17  SIGN MAINTENANCE REQUIRED.
   Signs shall at all times be kept clean and in good general repair and
appearance by the property owner or lessee. Signs not properly maintained shall
be deemed obsolete.
(Ord. 29-2002.  Passed 11-21-02.)
826.18  OBSOLETE SIGNS PROHIBITED.
   Signs which become obsolete for any reason are unlawful and subject to
removal under Section
826.23.
(Ord. 29-2002.  Passed 11-21-02.)
826.19  NONCONFORMING SIGNS.
   Any sign lawfully existing on the effective date of this chapter which does
not conform to all the standards and regulations of this chapter shall be
deemed lawfully nonconforming, and shall be subject to the following
regulations:
   (a)   Minor repairs, message alterations and ordinary maintenance may be
undertaken without a permit; however, no structural design alterations or
changes in the size or shape of the sign shall be made except to make the sign
comply with the requirements of this chapter.
   (b)   Any nonconforming sign that is voluntarily changed in size or shape,
structurally altered, relocated or replaced shall comply with all of the
provisions of this chapter as if it were a new sign.
   (c)   If a nonconforming sign is damaged by more than 50% of its replacement
value, it shall be removed and shall not be repaired or replaced except in
conformance with this chapter.
(Ord. 29-2002.  Passed 11-21-02.)
826.20  SIGNS ASSOCIATED WITH NONCONFORMING LAND USES.
   In the case of lawfully nonconforming land uses, such as a business located
in an area later zoned residential, the allowable message area shall be that
which would be in effect if the existing use were located in the most
restrictive zoning district allowing such land use, provided, however, that new
signs associated with nonconforming land uses in residential zoning districts
shall be only as permitted for home occupations. Further, no new signs
associated with nonconforming land uses shall be erected, except replacements
that are the same or smaller in size than the sign being replaced. In the event
that a sign associated with a nonconforming land use is moved or replaced, its
new size and location must conform to requirements of this chapter. If a legal
nonconforming land use is discontinued for more than 6 months, all signs
associated with the discontinued use shall be deemed obsolete, even if their
message is removed, covered or otherwise obscured.
(Ord. 29-2002.  Passed 11-21-02.)
826.201  TEMPORARY SIGNS.
   Animated or portable signs shall be permitted as temporary signs. Temporary
signs shall be subject to the following provisions:
   (a)   Time Period.  One temporary sign and support structure, if necessary,
may be erected for up to 2 time periods for a portable sign or 3 time periods
for a banner sign during any calendar year, provided that a minimum of 60
calendar days pass between time periods, regardless of calendar year when at
least one time period involves a portable sign. A minimum of 30 calendar days
must pass between time periods when both time periods involve banner signs. A
"Time Period" shall consist of 30 consecutive calendar days for a portable sign
or 60 consecutive calendar days for a banner sign.  A separate temporary sign
permit shall be required for each time period, provided no more  than 3 permits
shall be granted during any calendar year. However, a permit may be submitted
once per year, subject to the provisions of division (i) of this section. A
time period shall not be subdivided into smaller increments to permit the
placement of a temporary sign on a property, or segment of such property, more
than the maximum number of  times within any calendar year. Temporary signs
erected for more than the allowed  time period or for more than the number of
allowable time periods during a calendar year shall be considered permanent
signs and subject to all regulations for permanent signs.
   (b)   Attachment.  A temporary sign shall not be permanently attached to the
ground, buildings, or other structures.
   (c)   Banners and Flags.  One banner or flag is allowed per principal
building frontage, and shall not exceed 60 square feet. One balloon or
dirigible-like structure over 2 feet in length shall be permitted. Balloons of
inconsequential size (less than 2 feet) and number shall not be regulated
provided they do not become a public nuisance or traffic hazard. Additional
flags may be permitted, provided their size is inconsequential, but may not
extend into the right-of-way. During any time period, a banner, flag, or
balloon may be changed in content or location, provide advance notice is given
to the City of the change, the change shall not extend the time period, and
provided the proposed change does not violate the Codified Ordinances of
Trenton.
   (d)   Portable Signs.  No portable sign shall be greater than a maximum size
32 square feet.
   (e)   Number.  One temporary sign shall be permitted per site.
   (f)   Height.  Temporary signs on buildings shall not be placed above roof
lines, except as stated below. Portable signs shall not exceed 8 feet in height
as measured from the ground beneath the sign. Balloons generally shall not
exceed 50 feet in height but may be restricted further upon determination that
traffic safety or the public welfare is served by a shorter height. One
inflatable balloon or dirigible-like structure shall be permitted above the
building roof line for a period not to exceed one week per calendar year,
subject to the provisions of this section.
   (g)   Setbacks and Extensions into the Right-of-Way.  Temporary signs shall
maintain a minimum setback of 15 feet and shall not extend into the right-of-
way.
   (h)   Lighting and Movement.  Temporary signs shall not be illuminated or
have moving or rotating parts.
   (i)   Permit Fees and Bonding.  A temporary sign permit shall bear a non-
refundable fee equal to those fees outlined in Section
826.21. Additionally, each applicant, at the time of application approval,
shall remit a one hundred dollar ($100.00) bond, in the form of cash, personal
check, certified check, or money order payable to the City. Said bond shall be
returned to the applicant only if the temporary sign is removed within 48 hours
of the expiration date of the temporary sign permit. Failure to remove the
temporary sign within the required time frame shall constitute forfeiture of
said bond. The City Manager may, at his or her sole discretion, waive the
bonding requirement for not-for-profit civic organizations. A single annual
temporary sign permit may be submitted each calendar year for multiple time
periods with the following provisions:
      (1)   The applicant shall provide a complete and accurate schedule of the
time periods and shall not vary from that schedule during the calendar year;
      (2)   The applicant shall identify the type, size, location and content
of each temporary sign at the time of application and shall notify the City in
advance of any change in content or location.
      (3)   One permit fee and one bond may be submitted, provided the bond is
in a negotiable instrument that does not expire during that calendar year;
      (4)   An annual temporary sign permit shall expire on December 31 of each
calendar year; and
      (5)   Failure to adhere to the provisions of this section shall result in
the immediate revocation of the annual temporary sign permit and bond, in
addition to the abatement and enforcement actions authorized therein.
   (j)   Variances, Appeals and Fees.  The provisions of Sections
826.24 and
826.25 shall apply to this section, provided, however, that an application for
variance or appeal to these provisions shall be set at three hundred dollars
($300.00).
(Ord. 5-2003.  Passed 2-6-03; Ord. 32-2003. Passed 9-4-03; Ord. 42-2003. Passed
11-20-03.)
826.21  SIGN PERMIT APPLICATION AND FEES.
   (a)   No sign, except those listed in Sections
826.04 and
826.05, shall be erected, installed or otherwise displayed in the City without
a permit having been first obtained by application to the Zoning Inspector. 
Permits shall not be required for normal maintenance or repair of an existing
sign not involving structural design changes, or for message revisions which
maintain conformity with this chapter. All sign permits are issued subject to
the appeal provisions of Section
826.24.
   (b)   Permits shall bear a fee of two dollars ($2.00) for each square foot
of message area, or fifty dollars ($50.00), whichever is greater. However,
permits issued for signs already erected or being displayed at the time of
permit application shall bear a fee of four dollars ($4.00) for each square
foot of message area, or one hundred dollars ($100.00), whichever is greater.
   (c)   Sign permits may also be subject to State of Ohio surcharges.
   (d)   Sign permit applications for parcels having more than one occupant,
such as office buildings and shopping centers, may be made only by the owner or
owner's agent.
(Ord. 29-2002.  Passed 11-21-02.)
826.22  ENFORCEMENT RESPONSIBILITY.
   Initial enforcement of this chapter shall be the responsibility of such
municipal personnel as may be designated by the City Manager. The City
Prosecutor shall prosecute violators following the issuance of a citation.
(Ord. 29-2002.  Passed 11-21-02.)
826.23  REMOVAL OF UNLAWFUL SIGNS.
   (a)   Any sign that violates the provisions of this chapter is a public and
private nuisance, and the City shall give 7 days notice by personal service or
by registered or certified mail to the owner or lessee of the land on which
such sign is located, to remove such sign. However, in the case of an unlawful
sign that is not permanently attached to the ground or to a building or
structure, the City need give only 24 hours notice to remove the sign. The
owner or lessee shall have the right of appeal to the Board of Zoning Appeals.
   (b)   If any such sign has not been removed on or before the expiration of
the applicable notice period prescribed in division (a) of this section, or
within 7 days after the adverse decision of the Board of Zoning Appeals, the
City or any of its duly authorized agents may enter upon the premises and
cover, remove, or otherwise abate the sign. The cost of such covering, removal,
or abatement shall be paid out of any money in the City Treasury not otherwise
appropriated. City Council shall make a written return to the County Auditor
with a statement of the charges for services in covering, removing, or abating
the sign, together with a legal description of the parcel. Such amounts shall
be certified to the County Auditor for entry upon the tax duplicate, shall
constitute a lien upon such lands from the date of the entry, and shall be
collected as other taxes and returned to the City's General Fund.
   (c)   Notice to the owner or lessee shall not be required prior to the
removal of a hazardous sign which, in the opinion of the City Manager, creates
an immediate danger to persons or property due to structural design
deficiencies, inadequate maintenance or improper location. The City's entry
onto private property for the purpose of removing a hazardous sign shall not
constitute a trespass. Notice to the owner or lessee shall not be required
prior to the removal of any sign unlawfully placed on public property.
(Ord. 29-2002.  Passed 11-21-02.)
826.24  APPEALS AND FEES.
   (a)   Any written decision by the City Manager or his or her designee under
Section
826.22 may be appealed to the Board of Zoning Appeals by any person directly
and adversely affected, if such appeal is filed within 10 days after the date
of the decision. A properly filed application appealing the decision of the
City Manager or designee relative to the legality of a sign under this chapter
shall stay all abatement action until a decision on that appeal is made by the
Board of Zoning Appeals, except for removal of a hazardous sign under the
provisions of Section
826.23(c).
   (b)   Applications for appeal shall bear a non-refundable fee of one hundred
dollars ($100.00).
(Ord. 29-2002.  Passed 11-21-02.)
826.25  VARIANCES AND FEES.
   (a)   A variance from any provision of this chapter except message area or
allowable message area may be granted by the Board of Zoning Appeals where the
strict interpretation of this chapter would create an unusual and unnecessary
hardship on the property owner or occupant due to the unique location or
physical characteristics of the property, if such variance would not adversely
affect the public interest in any substantial manner, and if the relevant
physical characteristics of the property were not caused by a current or
previous owner or occupant. Intentional acts by an owner or occupant officially
approved by the City shall not operate as a bar to the determination of a
hardship.
   (b)   The City Planning Commission shall have authority to approve variances
from the provisions of this chapter, but only when a comprehensive signage plan
is submitted by a developer as part of the final development plan for a planned
unit development. In such cases, the Planning Commission shall endeavor to
maintain consistency with this chapter to the maximum extent feasible.
   (c)   The Board of Zoning Appeals shall not have authority to approve any
sign with a message area exceeding that permitted by this chapter, or to permit
the total message area to exceed the allowable message area permitted by this
chapter.
   (d)   In the event that a sign is established in violation of any provision
of this chapter, no application for a variance allowing such sign shall be
accepted, processed or reviewed by the Board of Zoning Appeals while the
illegal sign remains in place.
   (e)   Following disapproval by the Board of Zoning Appeals of an application
or request for a variance, no subsequent application requesting the same
variance shall be filed by any applicant, whether or not the same person, firm
or corporation, until the expiration of 12 months after the disapproval.
   (f)   Applications for variances shall bear a non-refundable fee of two
hundred dollars ($200.00).
   (g)   Although these sign regulations are business regulations and not
zoning, the notice and hearing procedures provided by Ohio law for zoning
variances shall be utilized for sign variances under this chapter. Defects in
the administration of such notice and hearing procedures shall not invalidate
any action of the Planning Commission or Board of Zoning Appeals.
(Ord. 29-2002.  Passed 11-21-02.)
826.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor of the third degree and shall be fined not more than five hundred
dollars ($500.00), or imprisoned not more than 60 days, or both. Each day that
a violation continues shall be deemed a separate offense and shall be
punishable as such hereunder.
(Ord. 29-2002.  Passed 11-21-02.)
CHAPTER 830
Garage Sales
830.01   Garage sale defined.
830.02   Purpose.
830.03   Registration required.
830.04   Registration fee not required.
830.05   Hours of sale.
830.06   Frequency and length of sales.
830.07   Permitted merchandise.
830.08   Advertising.
830.09   Application to Zoning Code.
 
830.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Licensing in general - see B.R. & T. Ch.
804
830.01  GARAGE SALE DEFINED.
   "Garage sale" means any sale of personal property to the general public
conducted on any portion of the residence property within a residential zoning
district, including but not limited to, garage sales, patio sales, carport
sales, basement sales, porch sales, driveway sales and the like.
(Ord. 5-76. Passed 7-15-76.)
830.02  PURPOSE.
   The purpose of this chapter is to regulate and control garage sales
conducted on the premises of residences within residential zoning districts. It
is not the purpose of this chapter to prevent a nonprofit organization from
conducting garage sales on real estate owned and/or occupied by such
organization, or one such sale annually on real estate owned by a member.
(Ord. 5-76. Passed 7-15-76.)
830.03  REGISTRATION REQUIRED.
   No person shall conduct a garage sale without first having registered with
the Zoning Administrator by transmitting the following information via
telephone or in person:
   (a)   The name of the person conducting such sale;
   (b)   The address of the property on which the sale is to be conducted; and
   (c)   The beginning and ending dates of such sale.
(Ord. 5-76. Passed 7-15-76. )
830.04  REGISTRATION FEE NOT REQUIRED.
   There shall be no fee for the registration required in Section
830.03.
(Ord. 5-76. Passed 7-15-76. )
830.05  HOURS OF SALE.
   Garage sales shall not commence before 10:00 a. m. and must terminate by 7:
00 p. m.
(Ord. 5-76. Passed 7-15-76.)
830.06  FREQUENCY AND LENGTH OF SALES.
   No person shall conduct more than two garage sales on his premises in any
one calendar year, or any sale exceeding a four-day period.
(Ord. 5-76. Passed 7-15-76.)
830.07  PERMITTED MERCHANDISE.
   Persons conducting garage sales shall offer only used unwanted items of
personal property owned by the resident of the property where the sale is held.
No such person shall offer any merchandise for sale that has been purchased by
the resident for the purpose of resale at such garage sale. Any new merchandise
offered for sale shall be prima-facie evidence of merchandise purchased by the
resident for resale at such garage sale.
(Ord. 5-76. Passed 7-15-76.)
830.08  ADVERTISING.
   (a)   Garage sales may be advertised through the newspaper or other news
media. A sign, not greater in size than three feet by three feet, may be
installed on the property where the sale is being conducted.
   (b)   No person shall place any such sign on the public right of way or on
property other than where the sale is being conducted. No person shall use a
lighted sign.
   (c)   Signs shall be displayed only during the sale and shall be promptly
removed after the sale.
(Ord. 5-76. Passed 7-15-76. )
830.09  APPLICATION TO ZONING CODE.
   It is not the intention of this chapter to change or amend the Zoning Code
of the City.
(Ord. 5-76. Passed 7-15-76. )
830.99  PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
804.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided. )
CHAPTER 850
Self-Service Gasoline Service Stations
850.01   Operating standards.
850.02   Smoking prohibited.
850.03   Regulations for operation.
 
850.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Gasoline, oils and paints - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 3741
850.01  OPERATING STANDARDS.
   Each filling station (as defined in Ohio R.C. 3741.13) within the City that
offers self-service shall be operated in accordance with the provisions of Ohio
R.C. Chapter 3741 and any amendments thereto, and standards adopted thereunder
by the State Fire Marshal.
(Ord. 4-77. Passed 2-3-77.)
850.02  SMOKING PROHIBITED.
   No person (whether owner, operator, customer, bystander or otherwise) shall
dispense gasoline or other flammable liquid at a self-service filling station
while such person is smoking or otherwise holding a lighted cigarette, cigar or
pipe.
(Ord. 4-77. Passed 2-3-77.)
850.03  REGULATIONS FOR OPERATION.
   No owner, operator, personnel supervisor, employee or attendant of a self-
service filling station shall knowingly permit or allow gasoline or other
flammable liquids to be dispensed at such filling station unless the following
standards are complied with:
   (a)   Each filling station offering self-service shall be under the direct
control of a supervisor, employee or attendant at all times when gasoline or
other flammable liquids are being dispensed or sold;
   (b)   Only persons properly trained in handling emergencies of flammable
fuel type shall be permitted to staff a filling station offering self-service;
   (c)   Gasoline and other flammable liquids shall be dispensed only by a
person who is not smoking and who in the judgment of such supervisor, employee
or attendant appears to be able and competent;
   (d)   A sign, in block letters at least four inches in height, shall be
conspicuously displayed on each gasoline pump island where self-service is
offered stating that it is a self-service island;
   (e)   Signs giving instructions for the operation of gasoline dispensing
equipment, in block letters at least one-half inch in height, shall be
conspicuously posted at each self-service filling station offering self-
service;
   (f)   A sign bearing the following words in block letters at least two
inches in height shall be conspicuously posted on each gasoline pump island
where self-service is offered:
      (1)   "STOP ENGINE";
      (2)   "NO SMOKING"; and
      (3)   "WARNING - IT IS UNLAWFUL AND DANGEROUS TO DISPENSE GASOLINE INTO
UNAPPROVED CONTAINERS."
   (g)   All signs required by this section shall be two-faced, conspicuous to
both sides of the traffic island and constructed of rigid weather-resistant
material; and
   (h)   Gasoline dispensing nozzles used by any person other than a
supervisor, employee or attendant shall be of an approved automatic closing
type without a hold-open latch.
(Ord. 4-77. Passed 2-3-77.)
850.99  PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
804.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 860
Taxicabs
860.01   Taxicab defined.
860.02   Taxicab license required.
860.03   Taxicab license application.
860.04   Taxicab license issuance; supporting documents.
860.05   License fee.
860.06   Display of license.
860.07   Effective period.
860.08   Taxicab stands.
860.09   Display of rates; excessive charges.
860.10   Chauffeur's license required.
860.11   Taxicab license renewal.
860.12   Revocation of taxicab license for nonuse.
 
860.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Operation of vehicles generally - see TRAF. Ch.
432
   DWI; reckless operation; speed - see TRAF. Ch.
434
   Vehicle equipment - see TRAF. Ch.
438
   Parking- see TRAF. Ch.
452
860.01  TAXICAB DEFINED.
   "Taxicab" means a vehicle whose owner or driver solicits, secures or accepts
passengers for hire upon hail or request on the public streets in the City.
(Ord. 615.  Passed 3-21-57.)
860.02  TAXICAB LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall operate, or cause to be operated, a taxicab, or proffer the
services of any vehicle as a taxicab unless the owner of such vehicle has
obtained a taxicab license covering such vehicle as provided in this chapter.
(Ord. 615.  Passed 3-21-57.)
860.03  TAXICAB LICENSE APPLICATION.
   Each applicant for a taxicab license shall present and file with the
Treasurer his signed application setting forth the trade name under which he
intends to do business, the number of vehicles and a general description of
each vehicle for which a license is desired, the marking or lettering to be
used thereon and any other information required by the Treasurer pertinent to
the issuance of such license.
860.04  TAXICAB LICENSE ISSUANCE; SUPPORTING DOCUMENTS.
   The Treasurer shall investigate and hold a hearing upon each application for
a taxicab license. If the Treasurer finds upon such investigation and hearing
that the public convenience and necessity do not justify the operation of the
vehicle for which such license is desired, he shall forthwith notify the
applicant of his findings. If he finds from such investigation and hearing that
the public convenience and necessity do justify the operation of the vehicle
for which such license is desired he shall forthwith notify the applicant.
Within sixty days thereafter, the applicant shall furnish and file with the
Treasurer the following:
   (a)   A full transcript of the information appearing on the certificate of
title of each vehicle for which the license is desired, and the State license
number of each such vehicle;
   (b)   The name of each person who will operate such taxicab, with the
chauffeur's license number of each such person;
   (c)   A policy of liability insurance issued for the life of the license
applied for or longer, by a responsible insurance company, approved as to
sufficiency by the Treasurer, and as to legality by the City Attorney,
providing indemnity for or protection to the applicant against loss resulting
from the operation of each such taxicab to the extent of one hundred thousand
dollars ($100,000) on account of injury or death of one person in any one
accident, three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000) on account of injury or
death of more than one person in any one accident, and fifty thousand dollars
($50,000) for property damage caused in any one accident. In lieu of such
policies of insurance, the applicant may furnish a bond binding the principal
and sureties to liability for the payment of a judgement in such amounts, with
at least two approved persons as sureties or one approved corporate surety,
approved as to sufficiency by the Treasurer and as to legality by the City
Attorney.
   Thereupon, the Treasurer shall examine such supporting information and
documents, and being satisfied that the applicant is the owner of any such
vehicle, that the same is a safe and fit conveyance, and that satisfactory
insurance or bond has been issued and is in force thereon, he shall, upon
payment of the prescribed license fee, issue a license to the applicant.
860.05  LICENSE FEE.
   The fee for the taxicab license shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) per year.
Licenses issued on or after July 1 of any year shall be issued at one-half the
annual license fee.
(Ord. 615.  Passed 3-21-57.)
860.06  DISPLAY OF LICENSE.
   A certified copy of the taxicab license shall be exhibited in a prominent
place in each taxicab at all times.
(Ord. 615.  Passed 3-21-57.)
860.07  EFFECTIVE PERIOD.
   Every taxicab license shall expire on December 31 of the year in which
issued.
(Ord. 615.  Passed 3-21-57.)
860.08  TAXICAB STANDS.
   At the time of issuing the taxicab license, the Director of Safety shall
designate a regular parking space for the taxicab or taxicabs, and he may
prescribe rules for usage of such stand suitable to applicant's business and
agreeable with the public convenience and welfare.
860.09  DISPLAY OF RATES; EXCESSIVE CHARGES.
   Every taxicab shall display at all times a printed list of the fares and
rates to be charged passengers for transportation. No owner or driver shall
charge an amount in excess of such printed rates unless by mutual agreement
between passenger and driver entered into before leaving the point of
departure.
(Ord. 615.  Passed 3-21-57.)
860.10  CHAUFFEUR'S LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person under eighteen years of age and no person other than a chauffeur,
duly licensed as such under the laws of the State, shall operate a taxicab on
any street or alley of the City.
860.11  TAXICAB LICENSE RENEWAL.
   All owners of taxicabs licensed under this chapter, at the completion of the
year for which such license was issued, shall be entitled to a renewal for each
succeeding year without a finding of convenience or necessity, provided that
all other requirements of this chapter have been complied with.
(Ord. 615.  Passed 3-21-57.)
860.12  REVOCATION OF TAXICAB LICENSE FOR NONUSE.
   Whenever a taxicab licensee fails to make a reasonable or consistent effort
to operate a taxicab for a period of sixty days, the Treasurer may either
suspend or revoke such license pursuant to the provisions of Section
804.08.
860.99  PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
804.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 870
Vendors and Solicitors
870.01   Definitions.
870.02   License required; fee.
870.03   Exceptions.
870.04   Regulations for peddling and soliciting.
870.05   Special event permit.
 
870.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Home solicitation sales - see Ohio R.C. 1345.21 et seq.
   Charitable solicitations - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 1716
   Frozen desserts - see Ohio R.C. 3717.51 et seq.
   Littering - see GEN. OFF.
660.03
870.01  DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   "Itinerant vendor" means any person, natural or artificial, who
engages in or conducts a temporary or transient business of selling goods,
wares and merchandise within the City, but does not intend to continue in such
business in any one location for more than four months and who, for the purpose
of carrying on such business, hires, leases or occupies in whole or in part any
room, building or structure for the exhibition and sale of such goods, wares
and merchandise.
   (b)   "Peddler" means any person who sells, offers for sale, barters or
exchanges any goods, wares, produce, merchandise or other articles of value at
any place in, upon, along or through the streets, alleys or other public ways
or places of the City or from house to house.
   (c)   "Solicitor" means any person who, without prior request, or without
being invited to do so by the owner or occupant of a private residence,
attempts to sell or solicit orders for the sale of goods, wares, merchandise or
other articles of value, including magazines, periodicals or books to be
delivered at a later time.
   (d)   "Hawker" or "itinerant retailer" means any person who carries those
goods, merchandise or articles of value referred to in subsection (c) hereof on
his person or in the vicinity for delivery the same day.
870.02  LICENSE REQUIRED; FEE.
   (a)   No peddler, itinerant vendor, solicitor, hawker or itinerant retailer
shall sell or offer for sale any goods, merchandise, produce or anything of
value in the City, or solicit or hawk any goods, merchandise or anything of
value, without first obtaining a license therefor from the Treasurer or the
Police Department, which license shall be carried on his person and shall be
displayed upon request to any member of the Police Department or any customer
or any person solicited.
   (b)   There shall be no fee for the license provided for in subsection (a)
hereof.
   (c)   Licenses issued under this section shall be valid for a period of not
greater than any one calendar year.
(Ord. 14-2009.  Passed 9-17-09.)
870.03  EXCEPTIONS.
   The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to the following:
   (a)   The owner of any product of his own raising;
   (b)   The manufacturer of any article manufactured by him within the City
who, by himself or his agent, peddles or vends any such article or product;
   (c)   Any person who, by State or Federal law or constitutional provision,
has been exempted from obtaining a license;
   (d)   Any sale under the order of a court or at a bona fide auction;
   (e)   Any sale at wholesale to a retail dealer;
   (f)   Four or more itinerant vendors associated together in an enterprise
such as a "flea market," stamp or coin collectors' "bourse," trade show, or the
like; 
   (g)   Any fraternal, civic or service organization conducting an occasional
sale, market or other fund-raising enterprise for charitable or civic purposes;
or
   (h)   Any local religious group or representative thereof offering or
soliciting orders for periodicals, tracts or publications of such religious
group.
870.04  REGULATIONS FOR PEDDLING AND SOLICITING.
   (a)   No peddler, solicitor, hawker or itinerant retailer shall park, stand
or stop, for the purpose of making any sale, within 200 feet of any school
between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. during the school term.
   (b)   No peddler, solicitor, hawker or itinerant retailer shall make any
sale or any delivery to any person from any motor vehicle or other conveyance
while such person is standing on, or is within, any public street, alley or
right-of-way normally used by motor vehicles.
   (c)   No peddler, solicitor, hawker or itinerant retailer shall use or
operate any noise-producing device, loudspeaker, chime or bell on any vehicle,
whether motor or manually operated, while such vehicle is in motion or
standing, to advertise or call attention to such person’s presence or product.
   (d)   Each peddler’s vehicle shall be equipped with a receptacle for the
disposal of wrappings, papers, envelopes or other containers for his or her
goods or merchandise, and no peddler shall fail to pick up and dispose of such
wrappers, papers, envelopes or containers after any sale or delivery of his or
her product before moving to another location or place.
   (e)   No peddler, solicitor, hawker or itinerant retailer shall make any
sale or any delivery, park, stand or stop, for the purpose of making any sale,
between the hours of 6:00 p.m. and 9:00 a.m. on any authorized day.
   (f)   No peddler, solicitor, hawker or itinerant retailer shall make any
sale or any delivery, park, stand or stop, for the purpose of making any sale
on Sundays or holidays.
   (g)   Whoever violates this section shall be subject to the penalties
provided in Section
870.99
(Ord. 14-2009.  Passed 9-17-09.)
870.05  SPECIAL EVENT PERMIT.
   (a)   Whenever a person, party or other entity desires to use City property
for purposes of a special event, parade, celebration or other activity
involving the property of the City and more than ten people, a special event
permit shall be completed and submitted to the City Manager at least ten
business days prior to the event occurrence.
   (b)   The special event permit will be submitted to the City Manager, Chief
of Police, Fire Chief and Service Director for approval. Final approval rests
solely with the City Manager, who shall review the permit application and
approve or  reject said application at least five business days prior to the
event occurrence.
   (c)   No fee shall be charged for this permit.
   (d)   No special event shall occur without a special event permit required
under this section submitted and approved as required above.
   (e)   Whoever violates this section shall be subject to the penalties
provided in Section
870.99.
(Ord. 23-2001.  Passed 6-21-01.)
870.99  PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
804.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 880
Adult Entertainment Businesses
880.01   Title.
880.02   Purpose and intent.
880.03   Administration and enforcement.
880.04   Definitions.
880.05   Permit required.
880.06   Locational limitations.
880.07   Design requirements.
880.08   Operational requirements.
880.09   Inspections.
880.10   Fees.
 
880.99   Penalties.
880.01  TITLE.
   This chapter shall be known and may be cited and referred to as the Trenton,
Ohio "Adult Entertainment Business Regulation Code," hereinafter "this Code."
(Ord. 28-2002.  Passed 11-21-02.)
880.02  PURPOSE AND INTENT.
   The purpose of this chapter is to promote the public health, safety, and
morals as they may be affected by sexually-oriented adult entertainment
businesses. The intent of this chapter is to achieve numerous important
community objectives, including but not limited to the following:
   (a)   Prevent the spread of sexually-transmitted disease.
   (b)   Protect children from exposure to inappropriate activities and themes.
   (c)   Minimize conflicts between sexually-oriented adult entertainment
businesses and other land uses.
   (d)   Facilitate the enforcement of obscenity laws.
   (e)   Protect property values.
   (f)   Discourage and prevent criminal activity.
   (g)   Prevent urban blight and other adverse secondary effects on the
community.
   (h)   Preserve the quality of urban life.
(Ord. 28-2002.  Passed 11-21-02.)
880.03  ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT.
   This chapter shall be administered and enforced by the City Manager or the
City Manager's designee.  All enforcement actions shall be subject to appeal to
the Board of Zoning Appeals, whose decision shall be final.
(Ord. 28-2002.  Passed 11-21-02.)
880.04  DEFINITIONS.
   An "Adult Entertainment Business" shall be defined as an enterprise having,
as a significant portion of its function, sexually-oriented adult entertainment
which offers all or part of one or more of the following listed products,
services or activities:
   (a)   "Adult Book Store."  An establishment having as a substantial or
significant portion of its stock-in-trade books, magazines, and other
periodicals that are distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on matter
depicting, describing, or relating to "Specified Sexual Activities" or
"Specified Anatomical Areas" as defined of this section.
   (b)   "Adult Entertainment Facility."  Any premises designed or used for the
sale of services or products characterized by the exposure or presentation of
specified anatomical areas or specified sexual activities, thereby appealing to
the prurient interest of patrons. Also, any premises which by their design or
furnishings facilitate sexual contact on the premises. Services or products
included within the scope of adult entertainment business are photography,
dancing, reading, massage, modeling and similar functions which involve
specified sexual activities or expose specified anatomical areas.
   (c)   "Adult Mini Motion Picture Theater."  A facility with a capacity for
less than 50 persons, used for presenting material distinguished or
characterized by an emphasis on matter depicting, describing or relating to
specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas, for observation by
patrons therein.
   (d)   "Adult Motion Picture Theater."  A facility with a capacity of 50 or
more persons, used for presenting material distinguished or characterized by an
emphasis on matter depicting, describing, or relating to specified sexual
activities or specified anatomical areas, for observation by patrons therein.
   (e)   "Massage."  A method of treating or stimulating the external parts of
the human body by rubbing, stroking, kneading, tapping, touching or vibrating
with the hand or any instruments for pay.
   (f)   "Massage Establishment."  Any establishment having a fixed place of
business where massages are administered for pay. This definition shall not be
construed to include a hospital, nursing home, or medical clinic; or the office
of a physician, surgeon, chiropractor, osteopath, physical therapist or
therapeutic massage therapist duly licensed by the State of Ohio; or barber
shops or beauty salons in which massages are administered only to the scalp,
the face, the neck, or the shoulders.
   (g)   "Rest Room."  A room with toilet and hand washing facilities in which
no products or services are offered for sale.
   (h)   "Specified Anatomical Areas."  Shall include the following:
      (1)   Less than completely and opaquely covered human genitals, public
region, buttock, and female breasts below a point immediately above the top of
the areola;
      (2)   Human male genitals in a discernibly turgid state even if
completely and opaquely covered.
   (i)   "Specified Sexual Activities."  Shall include the following:
      (1)   Human genitals in a state of sexual stimulation or arousal;
      (2)   Acts, real or simulated, of human masturbation, sexual intercourse,
sodomy, cunnilingus, or fellatio;
      (3)   Fondling or other erotic touching of human genitals, pubic region,
buttock, or female breasts.
(Ord. 28-2002.  Passed 11-21-02.)
880.05  PERMIT REQUIRED.
   (a)   Although this chapter is business regulation and not zoning, the Board
of Zoning Appeals, as an objective quasi-judicial body, shall have jurisdiction
to determine whether the requirements of this chapter have been met by a
proposed facility. A permit for the establishment of an adult entertainment
facility shall be issued by the City Manager upon receipt of a written finding
by the Board of Zoning Appeals that the location and design requirements of
this chapter will not be violated by the proposed facility, together with the
City Manager's finding of compliance with all other legal requirements of the
City.  Permits may be issued only to 1 or more specific individuals, and may
not be issued to incorporeal entities such as corporations, partnerships and
limited liability companies. The Board of Zoning Appeals may adopt such rules,
regulations and forms as it may find necessary to obtain information and
assurances from the applicant and determine whether a permit should be issued.
   (b)   Each permit granted shall be in effect for a period of 5 years unless
revoked or abandoned. A permit shall be deemed abandoned if the facility ceases
doing business for a period of 30 days or more. Renewals require a new
application and application fee.
(Ord. 28-2002.  Passed 11-21-02.)
880.06  LOCATIONAL LIMITATIONS.
   No adult entertainment facility shall be approved by the Board of Zoning
Appeals unless all of the following location requirements have been met:
   (a)   No adult entertainment facility shall be established within 500 feet
of any area zoned for residential use.
   (b)   No adult entertainment facility shall be established within a radius
of 1,000 feet of any school, library or teaching facility, whether public or
private, governmental or commercial, which school, library, or teaching
facility is attended by persons under 18 years of age.
   (c)   No adult entertainment facility shall be established within a radius
of 1,000 feet of any park or recreational facility attended by persons under 18
years of age.
   (d)   No adult entertainment facility shall be established within a radius
of 1,000 feet of any other adult entertainment facility or within a radius of
2,000 feet of any 2 of the following establishments:
      (1)   Cabarets, clubs, or other establishments that feature topless or
bottomless dancers, go-go dancers, exotic dancers, strippers, male or female
impersonators, or similar entertainers.
      (2)   Establishments for the sale of beer or intoxicating liquor for
consumption on the premises.
      (3)   Pawn shops.
      (4)   Pool or billiard halls.
      (5)   Pinball palaces, halls, or arcades.
      (6)   Dance halls or discotheques.
   (e)   No adult entertainment facility shall be established within a radius
of 1,000 feet of any church, synagogue, or permanently established place of
religious services that is attended by persons under 18 years of age.
   (f)   No adult entertainment facility may be established except in a
multiple-occupancy building where security is supplemented by surrounding
public activity.
   (g)   Divisions (a) through (e) of this section may be waived by the Board
of Zoning Appeals, provided that the applicant provides affidavits of 51% of
the property owners and resident freeholders within the above-described radii,
giving their consent to the establishment of an adult entertainment facility,
and if the Board of Zoning Appeals further determines:
      (1)   That the proposed use will not be contrary to the public interest
or injurious to nearby properties, and that the spirit and intent of this
section will be observed.
      (2)   That the proposed use will not enlarge or encourage the development
of a blighted area.
      (3)   That the establishment of an additional regulated use in the area
will not be contrary to any program of neighborhood conservation, nor will it
interfere with any program of urban renewal, residential or commercial
reinvestment, or renovation of a historical area.
      (4)   That all applicable regulations of this section will be observed.
   (h)   In the event that location limitations (a) through (f) of this section
operate to reduce the acreage available for adult entertainment facilities
below 5% of the total acreage in the City, the requirements shall be
sequentially waived by the Board of Zoning Appeals, commencing with division 
(f) of this section, until the 5% standard is met.
(Ord. 28-2002.  Passed 11-21-02.)
880.07  DESIGN REQUIREMENTS.
   No adult entertainment facility shall be permitted by the Board of Zoning
Appeals unless all of the following design requirements have been met:
   (a)   The facility meets the exterior lighting and parking requirements of
the zoning district in which it is located which are current at the time of
permit application.
   (b)   The interior space of the facility, including the arrangement of walls
and furnishings, is designed to permit continuous visual supervision of all
areas accessible to patrons by at least one of the facility's employees from
his or her assigned work station. Rest rooms are exempt from this requirement.
   (c)   No part of the facility is designed to permit any patron to have an
expectation of privacy when obtaining products or services or observing or
participating in activities offered by the facility.
(Ord. 28-2002.  Passed 11-21-02.)
880.08  OPERATIONAL REQUIREMENTS.
   No adult entertainment facility shall do any of the following:
   (a)   Permit any person under the age of 18 to enter the facility.
   (b)   Offer for sale or rent, or otherwise disseminate any obscene
materials.
   (c)   Knowingly permit, between its employees/agents/contractors and
patrons, or between or among patrons, any of the activities identified by
Section
880.04(h)(2) and (h)(3),  defining specified sexual activities.
   (d)   Fail to maintain continuous supervision of all patrons of the
facility.
   (e)   Fail to maintain the premises in a clean and sanitary condition.
(Ord. 28-2002.  Passed 11-21-02.)
880.09  INSPECTIONS.
   Employees or agents of the City, including members of the Board of Zoning
Appeals, may enter upon the premises of any adult entertainment facility at any
time during business hours, with or without notice or identification, for the
purpose of making inspections and determining whether the facility is in
compliance with all provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 28-2002.  Passed 11-21-02.)
880.10  FEES.
   Each application to establish an adult entertainment facility or to renew a
permit shall be accompanied by a fee of five hundred dollars ($500.00) to
partially defray the cost of processing the application and monitoring the
operation of the facility.
(Ord. 28-2002.  Passed 11-21-02.)
880.99  PENALTIES.
   (a)   In addition to any other sanctions, remedies or penalties provided by
law, the City Manager may suspend or revoke the permit of any adult
entertainment facility which materially fails to continue to meet the location,
design or operating requirements of this chapter. Suspensions and revocations
shall be imposed in a progressive manner, after notice and a hearing before the
City Manager, as follows:
      (1)   First violation:  30-day suspension of all business.
      (2)   Second violation:  90-day suspension of all business.
      (3)   Third Violation:  Revocation of permit.
   (b)   Suspensions and revocations shall be effective 10 days after notice is
given, unless appealed. The City Manager's decision may be appealed to the
Board of Zoning Appeals within 10 days after notice of the suspension or
revocation is received by the permittee or delivered to the facility. Such an
appeal shall stay the decision of the City Manager until the Board has acted.
The Board shall meet within 10 days after the appeal has been filed, or as soon
thereafter as scheduling permit . After notice and a hearing, the Board of
Zoning Appeals shall, within 10 days after the hearing, issue to the City
Manager its findings of fact and its determination as to whether a material
failure to comply with this chapter has occurred. If the Board finds that no
violation of this chapter has occurred, the City Manager shall rescind his
order of suspension or revocation. An appeal to the courts of a decision by the
Board upholding the decision of the City Manager shall not operate as a stay of
the City Manager's decision.
   (c)   Upon revocation of a permit, the permittee shall, within 30 days after
notice of said revocation, remove all goods, equipment and furniture associated
with the business from the premises, including exterior signage. No permittee
may, after having a permit for an adult entertainment facility revoked for
violations of this chapter, open an adult entertainment facility or otherwise
acquire an economic interest in such a facility within the City for a period of
five years after such revocation.
(Ord. 28-2002.  Passed 11-21-02.)
CHAPTER 885
Collection of Unpaid Bills
885.01   Collection of unpaid bills.
885.01  COLLECTION OF UNPAID BILLS.
   All collection costs, including those paid to agencies collecting funds on
behalf of the City, and those reasonably incurred in the filing of court
action, shall be added to and made a part of any such delinquent accounts owed
by any person or entity to the City for services rendered, taxes due, utility
payments due, court ordered fines and costs, administrative fines and fees, or
privileges granted and also including any court costs and attorney's collection
fees reasonably incurred in such collection process.
(Ord. 11-2010.  Passed 6-17-10.)
CHAPTER 887
Video Service Provider Fee
887.01   Establishment of fee.
887.02   Payment of fee.
887.03   Notification of fee percentage.
887.01   ESTABLISHMENT OF FEE.
   City Council hereby establishes a video service provider (VSP) fee that is
calculated by applying a VSP fee percentage of five percent to the video
service provider's gross revenues as defined in the Video Law, Ohio R.C.
1332.32(B).  All video service providers and cable television operators
providing video service in the City shall apply the VSP fee percentage against
gross revenues as defined in the Video Law.
(Ord. 16-2012.  Passed 7-19-12.)
887.02   PAYMENT OF FEE.
   The VSP fee shall be paid by each video service provider providing service
in the City on a quarterly basis but no sooner than forty-five days nor later
than sixty days after the end of each calendar quarter.
(Ord. 16-2012.  Passed 7-19-12.)
887.03   NOTIFICATION OF FEE PERCENTAGE.
   The City Manager is authorized  and directed to provide any video service
provider with notice of the VSP fee percentage as determined by City Council,
which notice shall be given by certified mail, upon receipt of notice from such
video service provider that it will begin providing video service in the City
pursuant to a State-issued video service authorization.
(Ord. 16-2012.  Passed 7-19-12.)
