safety reasons.
(Ord. 1-95. Passed 1-5-95.)
1488.04  APPEARANCE OF EXTERIOR PROPERTY AND STRUCTURE EXTERIORS.
   All buildings and the exterior of all premises shall be properly maintained
to achieve a presentable appearance and to avoid blighting effects and
hazardous conditions.
   (a)   Exterior Space. The exterior open space around each dwelling shall be
maintained or improved so as to provide for:
      (1)   The immediate diversion of water away from buildings and proper
drainage of the lot;
      (2)   Grass, plantings or other suitable ground cover to prevent soil
erosion which is or may become detrimental to the structures, lot use or
adjacent lots and structures; and
      (3)   Yard walks, parking areas and driveways of a concrete, asphalt,
paver or similar surface which are of sound construction and properly
maintained.
   (b)   Maintenance. The exterior of all premises and every structure thereon,
including, but not limited to, walls, roofs, chimneys, drains, towers, porches,
landings, fire escapes, stairs, signs, windows, doors, awnings and all surfaces
thereof, shall be maintained so as to avoid any blighting effects on
neighboring properties and shall be painted or protected where necessary for
the purpose of preservation. All canopies, marquees, signs, awnings, exterior
stairways, fire escapes, standpipes, exhaust ducts, porches, balconies and
similar overhanging extensions, where exposed to public view, shall be
maintained in good condition and shall not show evidence of ripping, tearing or
deterioration.
   (c)   Fences and Retaining Walls. All fences, retaining walls or similar
structures shall be anchored firmly in the ground, shall be constructed in a
workmanlike manner and shall be maintained in that same manner so that such
approved fences, retaining wall or similar structures shall always be in the
state of good structural repair. If any fence, retaining wall or similar
structure is found not to be in a state of good structural repair, it shall be
removed, replaced or repaired as required. Except when constructed of materials
that have been designed or manufactured to remain untreated, all fences shall
be treated periodically with paint or chemicals so as to retard deterioration.
   (d)   Yards. All yards, courts and lots shall be kept free of overgrown
grasses, debris and other materials which may cause a fire, health or safety
hazard or general unsightliness.
   (e)   Hazards. Hazards and unsanitary conditions shall be eliminated.
   (f)   Occupancy. No temporary buildings, trailers, recreational vehicles,
tents or garages shall be used temporarily or permanently as a residence in the
course of construction.
   (g)   Drainage. All portions of all premises shall be so graded that there
is no pooling of water or recurrent entrance of water into any part of any
building, except when such pooling or retention of water is part of a plan
approved by the Building Inspector. All condensate and waste cooling water
shall be appropriately discharged into an approved drainage system.
   (h)   Drainage Swales. Swales are to be maintained by the owners of the
parcels on which they are located, and at no time will anyone plant shrubs and/
or trees or discharge, empty or place any material, fill or waste into any
swale so as to divert or impede drainage flow. Small swales can be mowed as
part of the yard. Larger swales in meadow situations should be mowed less
frequently in order to allow grasses to grow taller to retard run-off and
prevent erosion. Swales in woodland areas should be left in their natural
condition leaving understory growth to retard run-off and prevent erosion.
   (i)   Traffic Markings. All traffic markings, such as directional arrows,
land division lines, parking space lines, stop signs, etc., shall be maintained
so as to be clearly visible and easily recognized.
   (j)   Conduct of Business.
      (1)   All business activity, except for off-street loading, shall be
conducted within completely enclosed buildings.
      (2)   All storage of materials, goods or products, including inoperable
vehicles, shall be within a completely enclosed building.
      (3)   Those businesses which are permitted or conditionally permitted
under the terms of the Zoning Code to conduct business or maintain storage of
materials, goods or products out-of-doors are excepted from compliance with
paragraphs (j)(1) and (2) hereof.
   (k)   Exterior Lighting Fixtures. Exterior lighting fixtures over steps,
paths, walkways, courts, drives and parking lots shall be neatly maintained in
operable condition, lighted for sufficient periods of time before and after
business hours to provide for pedestrian and employee safety and properly aimed
so as not to shine on adjacent properties.
(Ord. 1-95. Passed 1-5-95.)
1488.05  VEGETATION.
   All plant materials, especially trees and shrubs, afflicted with decay,
disease or insect infestation, or otherwise considered dangerous to other plant
material, shall be removed or appropriately treated. All sound plant materials,
especially trees and shrubs, shall be properly maintained and shall not
evidence signs of neglect.
(Ord. 1-95. Passed 1-5-95.)
1488.06  EXTERIOR STAIRWAYS.
   All exterior stairways on all industrial premises shall be constructed and
maintained in accordance with the following provisions:
   (a)   Stairways shall be maintained free of holes, grooves and cracks which
constitute a safety hazard;
   (b)   Stairways shall be maintained free of rotted or deteriorated supports;
   (c)   Stairways shall have treads of uniform width and risers of uniform
height; and
   (d)   Stairway handrails and/or railings shall be firmly fastened and
maintained in good condition. Where the absence of handrails and/or railings
creates a hazardous condition, the Enforcement Officer may require their
installation in accordance with the provisions of the Building Code.
(Ord. 1-95. Passed 1-5-95.)
1488.07  ACCESSORY STRUCTURES.
   All structures accessory to industrial uses, including detached garages,
shall be structurally sound, neatly maintained and in good repair, or shall be
razed to grade level and all debris removed from the premises.
(Ord. 1-95. Passed 1-5-95.)
1488.99  PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
1482.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 1490
Control of Excessively Tall Grass and Noxious Plants and Weeds
1490.01   Compliance required.
1490.02   Nuisance declared.
1490.03   Standards for maintenance of vegetation.
1490.04   Enforcement procedures.
1490.05   Municipal intervention and collection of costs.
 
1490.99   Penalty.
1490.01  COMPLIANCE REQUIRED.
   No owner or owners of any property within the City shall fail to reasonably
control grass, uncultivated vegetation, noxious weeds or plants, or obstacles
to the lawful maintenance of such property.  Such persons shall after written
notification be jointly and severally liable for any violation of the City
standards established by this section.
(Ord. 13-2012.  Passed 6-21-12.)
1490.02  NUISANCE DECLARED.
   Any violation of the standards established by this section is hereby
declared to be a nuisance actionable under municipal and/or Ohio law.
(Ord. 13-2012.  Passed 6-21-12.)
1490.03  STANDARDS FOR MAINTENANCE OF VEGETATION
   (a)    Grass and weeds shall be maintained at a height not to exceed eight
inches. 
   (b)    Trees, plants and weeds which have been identified as noxious or
invasive by the United States Department of Agriculture, the Ohio Department of
Agriculture, the Ohio Department of Natural Resources, or the Ohio State
University Extension Service (see, e.g., Bulletin 866-98), shall be eradicated
within thirty days after their discovery and identification.
   (c)   Exceptions to paragraphs (a) and (b) above:
      (1)   Established forest areas.  Naturally wooded areas shall be exempt
from the requirements set forth in (a) and (b) above.
      (2)   Parcels devoted to active farming.  Land used for active farming
(which includes agriculture and pasturing of livestock) shall be generally
exempt from the requirements set forth in (a) and (b) above. However, if any
portion of a parcel closer than thirty feet to a street right-of-way line or
the property line of a developed lot or parcel is not devoted to active
farming, these areas shall be considered "vacant land," subject to the
regulations set forth in (3) below.  For the purpose of this section, "active
farming" refers to those uses undertaken during the current year.
      (3)   Vacant land.  Unplatted parcels which are not devoted to active
farming shall be generally exempt from the requirements set forth in (a) and
(b) above.  However, grass and weeds within thirty feet of any street right-of-
way line shall be maintained at a height not to exceed twenty-four inches,
except grass and weeds located between a curb and sidewalk shall be maintained
at a height not to exceed eight inches.  Further, trees, plants and weeds which
have been identified as noxious or invasive located within thirty feet of the
property line of any developed lot or parcel shall be eradicated within thirty
days after their discovery and identification.
      (4)   Platted but undeveloped lots.  Each owner of an undeveloped lot
within a platted subdivision shall maintain grass and weeds at a height not to
exceed twelve inches, except grass and weeds located between a curb and
sidewalk shall be maintained at a height not to exceed eight inches.  Further,
trees, plants and weeds which have been identified as noxious or invasive
located within thirty feet of the property line of any developed lot or parcel
shall be eradicated within thirty days after their discovery and
identification. For the purpose of the preceding subsections (3) and (4),
"developed lot or parcel" means any land on which there is a building designed
for or suitable for residential use.
   (d)  Obstructions to lawful maintenance.  Regardless of its use, no parcel
or platted lot shall be altered so as to increase the accumulation of surface
water or to divert any accumulation of water onto adjacent properties except in
conformance with a drainage plan approved by the City.  Further, no owner of
any parcel or platted lot shall permit any soil, rocks, refuse or construction
debris to be deposited or remain which obstructs its being maintained in
conformance with the requirements of this section, except during the period of
active construction.  A lot or parcel shall be considered "actively under
construction" only during that period commencing with the issuance of the City
building permit for the principal structure and concluding with the issuance of
the City occupancy permit for that structure. 
(Ord. 13-2012.  Passed 6-21-12.)
1490.04  ENFORCEMENT PROCEDURES
   (a)   No person described in Section
1490.01 shall be charged with a violation of this Section without first being
actually or constructively notified in writing of such violation by the City
Manager or his designee.
   (b)   Upon becoming aware of an alleged violation, the City Manager or his
designee shall cause written notice thereof (hereinafter "the notice") to be
served upon the property owner(s) of record at their county-listed real estate
tax mailing address by first class mail.  This mailing shall be evidenced by a
certificate of mailing issued by the U.S. Postal Service and shall be deemed
"constructively received" by the owner or owners on the third day after
mailing, not including the date of mailing. 
      (1)   Alternatively, the City Manager or his designee shall cause the
notice to be served upon the owner(s) by personal service.  Such "actual
receipt" shall be evidenced by a "return of service" signed by the server.   
      (2)   The notice shall be dated, generally describe the alleged violation
(s) (hereinafter "the nuisances"), identify the regulation or regulations
invoked, and require the owner to correct the violations within seven days. 
The notice shall offer the opportunity to appeal the allegations in the notice
to the City Manager.  It shall also provide information to assist the recipient
in filing his appeal with the City Manager. 
   (c)   Upon actual or constructive receipt of the notice, whichever first
occurs, the owner shall cause the identified nuisances to be corrected within
seven days thereafter.  However, any owner or owner's authorized agent may,
within this seven day compliance period, appeal the alleged violation to the
City Manager on the basis that one or more of the alleged nuisances do not
exist.  Failure to appeal to the City Manager shall constitute a failure to
exhaust administrative remedies and shall preclude any appeal to the courts.
   (d)   An appeal filed with the City Manager during the seven day appeal
period described in (c) above shall stay all proceedings until the City Manager
confirms or overrules the nuisance allegations.  Following such an appeal, the
City Manager or his designee shall cause written notice of his decision
(hereinafter "the decision") to be served upon the property owner(s) of record
at their county-listed real estate tax mailing address by first class mail. 
This mailing shall be evidenced by a certificate of mailing issued by the U.S.
Postal Service and shall be deemed "constructively received" by the owner or
owners on the third day after mailing, not including the date of mailing. 
      (1)   Alternatively, the City Manager or his designee shall cause the
decision to be served upon the owner(s) by personal service.  Such "actual
receipt" shall be evidenced by a "return of service" signed by the server.   
      (2)   In the event that any nuisance is found by the City Manager, the
owner shall cure the nuisance within seven days after actual or constructive
receipt of the City Manager's decision.
(Ord. 13-2012.  Passed 6-21-12.)
1490.05  MUNICIPAL  INTERVENTION AND COLLECTION OF COSTS
   (a)   In the event that all the remaining identified nuisances have not been
cured within seven days following mailing of the notice, and the owner has not
filed an appeal with the City Manager, the City may at any time thereafter
enter onto the property and cure all remaining previously-identified
nuisances. 
   (b)   In the event that the owner has appealed the notice to the City
Manager, and after the City Manager finds that one or more of the cited
nuisances continue to exist after the extended compliance period, the City may,
at its option, within seven days after the violator's actual or constructive
receipt of the City Manager's decision, enter upon the property and cure all
nuisances cited in the original notice which remain.
   (c)   In the event that the City elects to enter onto the property to cure
nuisances as authorized in subsection (a) or (b) above, the City may, at its
option, and without further notice to the owner, lessee, agent, tenant,
occupant or other person having possession or charge of such property, continue
to enter upon the property from time to time in order to maintain control of
the identified nuisances, so long as the property remains titled in the name of
the originally-notified owner in the official records of the Auditor of Butler
County, Ohio. This right shall continue for the entire calendar year.
   (d)   The City shall not be responsible for any damage done to the premises
under the authorization provided in subsections (a), (b) and (c) above and
shall have the right to invoice the owner for all such work performed at the
liquidated cost of $120.00 per on-site man-hour, including all equipment,
equipment maintenance, supplies, and overhead costs, with a minimum charge of
$300.00. 
   (e)   If the owner does not pay for the work performed by the City pursuant
to the above subsections (a), (b) or (c) within thirty days following the
mailing of each invoice, the City may without further notice recover the
amounts authorized by the above subsection (d) using the collection procedures
set forth in Ohio R.C. 715.261 or any other legal means of collection.
(Ord. 13-2012.  Passed 6-21-12.)
1490.99  PENALTY.
   See Section
1482.99.
(Ord. 13-2012.  Passed 6-21-12.)

1610.01  1998 EDITION ADOPTED; PURPOSE.
   There is hereby adopted by the City, for the purpose of prescribing
regulations governing conditions hazardous to life and property from fire or
explosion, that certain code known as the Ohio Fire Code, recommended by the
State of Ohio, Department of Commerce, Division of State Fire Marshal, being
particularly the 1998 edition thereof, save and except such portions as are
hereinafter deleted, modified or amended.
1610.02  FILE AND DISTRIBUTION COPIES.
   One copy of the Ohio Fire Code, as adopted in Section
1610.01, is on file in the office of the Clerk of Council and available for
reference by interested persons.
1610.03  ENFORCEMENT.
   The Ohio Fire Code shall be enforced by the Fire Chief.
1610.04  STORAGE LIMITS. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Section
1610.04 was repealed as part of the 1979 revision and updating of these
Codified Ordinances.)

1610.09  CONFLICT OF LAWS.
   In the event of a conflict between any of the provisions of the Ohio Fire
Code adopted herein and a provision of this Part Sixteen - Fire Prevention Code
or any other local ordinance or provision, the stricter standard shall control.
1610.10  SEPARABILITY.
   Should any section, paragraph, sentence or word of this chapter or of the
Ohio Fire Code adopted in Section
1610.01 be declared to be invalid for any reason, Council hereby declares that
it would have passed all other portions of this chapter and such Code
independent of the elimination of any such portion as may be declared invalid.
1610.99  GENERAL CODE PENALTY.
   (a)    Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter, including the
provisions of the Ohio Fire Code, or fails to comply therewith, or violates or
fails to comply with any order made thereunder, or builds in violation of any
detailed statement of specifications or plans submitted and approved
thereunder, or any certificate or permit issued thereunder, and from which no
appeal has been taken, or fails to comply with such an order as affirmed or
modified by a court of competent jurisdiction, within the time fixed therein,
is severally for each and every such violation and noncompliance respectively,
guilty of a minor misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than one hundred
dollars ($100.00). The imposition of one penalty for any violation shall not
excuse the violation or permit it to continue, and all such persons shall be
required to correct or remedy such violations or defects within a reasonable
time. When not otherwise specified, a separate offense shall be deemed
committed each ten days that prohibited conditions are maintained.
   (b)    The application of the above penalty shall not be held to prevent the
enforced removal of prohibited conditions.

1612.01  2003 EDITION ADOPTED.
   Pursuant to the authority granted in Section
3.06 of the Charter of the City of Trenton, the most recent printing of the
International Fire Code (IFC), as published in 2003 by the International Code
council and which may be amended from time to time, is hereby adopted as the
Fire Prevention Code of the City for the control of buildings, provisions,
penalties, conditions and terms of said IFC, are hereby referred to, adopted
and made a part hereof as if fully set out in this chapter, save and except for

1612.01, shall be amended to allow any person the right to appeal a decision of
the Code Official to the Board of Building Examiners and Appeals as established
in Section
1404.03 of the Codified Ordinance of the City of Trenton.
(Ord. 10-2004. Passed 5-6-04.)

   One copy of the IFC, as adopted in Section
1612.01, shall remain on file in the office of the Clerk of Council and be
available for inspection or reference by interested persons.
(Ord. 10-2004. Passed 5-6-04.)
1612.04  PERMITS FOR NEW MATERIALS, PROCESSES OR OCCUPANCIES.
   The Fire Chief shall determine and specify, after giving affected persons an
opportunity to be heard, any new materials, processes or occupancies that will
require permits, in addition to those now enumerated in the IFC, as adopted in
Section
1612.01. The Chief shall post a list of such new materials, processes or
occupancies in a conspicuous place in his or her office and shall distribute
copies thereof to interested persons.
(Ord. 10-2004. Passed 5-6-04.)
1612.05  CONFLICT OF LAWS.
   In the event of a conflict between any of the provisions of the IFC, as
adopted in Section
1612.01, or any other local ordinance or provision, the stricter standards
shall prevail.
(Ord. 10-2004. Passed 5-6-04.)
1612.06  SEPARABILITY.
   Should any section, paragraph, sentence or word of this chapter or of the
IFC, as adopted in Section
1612.01, be declared for any reason to be invalid, it is the intent of Council
that it would have adopted all other portions of the same independent of the
elimination therefrom of any such portion as may be declared invalid.
(Ord. 10-2004. Passed 5-6-04.)
1612.99  PENALTY.
   (a)    Unless otherwise provided, whoever violates or fails to comply with
any of the provisions of this chapter, including any provision of the IFC
adopted in Section
1612.01, and including any order of the Fire Chief or his or her authorized
representative made pursuant thereof, or builds in violation of any detailed
statement of specifications or plans submitted and approved thereunder, or any
certificate or permit issued thereunder, and from which no appeal has been
taken, or fails to comply with such an order as affirmed or modified as
provided in this chapter, within the specified time, is guilty of a misdemeanor
of the third degree and shall be fined not more than five hundred dollars
($500.00), or imprisoned not more than 60 days, or both, for each offense.
Unless otherwise provided, a separate offense shall be deemed committed each
day during or on which a violation or noncompliance occurs or continues. 
   (b)    The application of the penalty provided in division (a) of this
section shall not be deemed to prevent the enforced removal of prohibited
conditions, or the application of any other equitable remedy, including
abatement of any nuisance.
(Ord. 10-2004. Passed 5-6-04.)
PART EIGHTEEN - CHRONIC NUISANCE PROPERTIES
         
Chap. 1802.    Chronic Nuisance Properties.
CHAPTER 1802
Chronic Nuisance Properties
1802.01   Purpose.
1802.02   Scope.
1802.03   Procedure for designation as a chronic nuisance property.
1802.04   Civil penalties.
1802.05   Due process and defenses.
1802.06   Abatement.
1802.07   Other remedies.
1802.08   Payments and collections.
1802.01  PURPOSE.
   The purpose of this chapter is to more effectively control repeated City
Code violations and repeated calls for service made to the Police Department,
in order to better serve the law-abiding occupants of the City and control the
cost of providing essential public services.
(Ord. 09-2017.  Passed 6-1-17.)
1802.02  SCOPE.
   (a)   (1)   Any property whose owner (or owners) has repeatedly and
knowingly caused, permitted or allowed City Code violations on owned property
may be determined to be a chronic nuisance property.
      (2)   For the purpose of this subsection (a), any activity that
unreasonably disturbs the peace, comfort, health, safety, and/or tranquility of
occupants of nearby properties or of the general neighborhood may constitute a
nuisance activity.  In no event shall the City be required to prove any
decrease in the values of neighboring properties in order to defend its
determination of a nuisance activity.
   (b)   Any property whose owner (or owners) has repeatedly and knowingly
caused, permitted or allowed criminal activity on owned property may be
determined to be a chronic nuisance property.
(Ord. 09-2017.  Passed 6-1-17.)
1802.03  PROCEDURE FOR DESIGNATION AS A CHRONIC NUISANCE PROPERTY.
   Upon a written recommendation by the Zoning Administrator, Police Chief,
Fire Chief, or other municipal department head, or any other governmental
official having jurisdiction over the property, the City Manager may find that
a property owner has allowed a property to become a chronic nuisance property
under this chapter.  No such finding shall be made unless:
   (a)   Two violations of the same City ordinance or Ohio Revised Code section
have been identified within a 365 day period and an official written notice was
delivered to the owner of the property after each violation, both by ordinary
mail and by posting such notice on the front door of any building on the
property.  A certificate of service dated and signed by the City employee who
mailed and posted such notice shall be attached to and placed in the
appropriate City file with each notice; and
   (b)   Any subsequent violation within the same 365 day period shall be
reviewed by the City Manager to determine if the property is a chronic nuisance
property.
(Ord. 09-2017.  Passed 6-1-17.)
1802.04  CIVIL PENALTIES.
   (a)   When a property has been determined to be a chronic nuisance property
under Section
1802.03 , a notification for payment of the prescribed civil penalty (the
"violation notice") shall be issued in writing to the owner(s) of the property.
This violation notice shall, at a minimum, be sent by certified mail to the tax
mailing address(s) on record at the Butler County Auditor's Office and shall
contain the following:
      (1)   The name(s) of the owner(s) of the property as listed with the
Butler County Auditor's Office;
      (2)   The address and parcel number of the property in violation;
      (3)   A copy of Code
Chapter 1802 , Chronic Nuisance Properties;
      (4)   A copy of the section of the City Code that was repeatedly violated
causing the property to be designated as a chronic nuisance property;
      (5)   The date of each violation of the City Code or Ohio Revised Code
that was repeatedly violated, causing the property to be designated as a
chronic nuisance property;
      (6)   A statement of the amount of the civil penalty due to the City of
Trenton under subsection (b) hereof, stipulating that the amount must be paid
in full to the City's Department of Finance within thirty days after the date
of the violation notice;
      (7)   A prominent notice that failure to pay the civil penalty within
thirty days of the date of the violation notice will result in the penalty
amount, with statutory interest, to be certified to Butler County Auditor's
Office for collection with the real estate taxes;
      (8)   The date by which the owner is required to abate the violation to
prevent another civil penalty from being assessed as provided by Section
1802.06, Abatement; and
      (9)   A prominent notice that subsequent violations of the same City Code
on the same property may result in additional civil penalties as provided by
subsection (b) hereof.
   (b)   Schedule of civil penalties under this chapter, which are in addition
to any other fines or penalties allowed by law for the same offence.
      (1)   First violation of this chapter - fifty dollars ($50.00).
      (2)   Second violation of this chapter - additional one hundred dollars
($100.00) within 365 days after the first violation of this chapter.
      (3)   Third violation of this chapter - additional two hundred fifty
dollars ($250.00) within 365 days after the second violation of this chapter.
      (4)   Fourth violation and all subsequent violations of this chapter -
additional five hundred dollars ($500.00).
      (5)   After one year without a repeat violation of this chapter, the
property shall no longer be designated a chronic nuisance property, but instead
shall be treated as if it had not been previously designated as such.
(Ord. 09-2017.  Passed 6-1-2017.)
1802.05  DUE PROCESS AND DEFENSES.
   (a)   Civil penalties shall be assessed against the person or persons listed
in the Butler County Auditor's Office as the owner(s) as of the date(s) of
violation.
   (b)   Within thirty days of the date of the violation notice, such owner(s)
may appeal the violation notice to the City Manager who shall offer a hearing
to such owner(s).
   (c)   If at such hearing, the owner(s) provide reliable documentation that
such owner(s) did not own the property at the time of one or more of the
violations supporting the violation notice, the City Manager shall waive any
civil penalty(s) imposed by this chapter and have the City's property file
corrected to reflect his determination of the facts.
   (d)   If at such hearing, the owner(s) provide reliable documentation that
they are actively and lawfully evicting the tenants who committed the nuisance
activity in question, the City Manager may agree to delay further enforcement,
delay with conditions, or decline to delay.  Any delay shall be for a specified
period not to exceed ninety days after such decision, unless subsequently
extended by the Manager for good cause shown.
   (e)   Any decision of the City Manager under this chapter may be appealed to
a court of competent jurisdiction.
(Ord. 09-2017.  Passed 6-1-17.)
1802.06  ABATEMENT.
   (a)   When a property has been determined to be a chronic nuisance property,
the City shall indicate in the notice required under Section
1802.04 (a) the date by which the violation shall be abated according to the
following:
      (1)   Immediate. When the violation poses an immediate and significant
threat to human life, health, safety or the natural environment. This notice
may be verbal due to the nature of the violation. If verbal notice cannot be
made within a sufficient time to eliminate the threat, the City may, at its
discretion, abate the violation to the best of its ability.
      (2)   Other circumstances. At the discretion of the City, any reasonable
or appropriate time requirements may be mandated for the owner(s) of the
property to abate the notified nuisance.
   (b)   If the property owner fails to abate the nuisance within the
prescribed time, the City may enter the property and abate it. All costs
incurred by the City, including management time and other overhead costs, shall
be invoiced to the property owner(s).  Payment shall be due thirty days after
the issuance of the invoice. The owner(s) shall be jointly and severally liable
for payment.
   (c)   Abatement of the nuisance by the City does not affect civil penalties
previously imposed or any other applicable fines or legal rights of the City.
(Ord. 09-2017.  Passed 6-1-17.)
1802.07  OTHER REMEDIES.
   (a)   Active permits granted to the owner(s) or tenant(s), including but not
limited to those for construction or occupancy, may be suspended or revoked by
the City Manager based on the determination that a property is a chronic
nuisance property.
   (b)   Vacant properties or vacant units within a chronic nuisance property
which has an unabated violation, unpaid fines or unpaid civil penalties shall
not qualify for occupancy permits or zoning certificates until all violations
are abated and all fines and penalties paid.
   (c)   The declaration of a nuisance property, the imposition of civil
penalties, suspension or revocation of permits, an order to abate a nuisance,
or the collection of the City's abatement costs under this chapter shall not
affect or limit the City's right or authority to bring a criminal prosecution
or other legal action against the property owner for these violations or any
other City ordinances or for civil damages; or under the Ohio Revised Code,
including but not limited to, those actions and remedies provided by Ohio R.C.
3767.06.
   (d)   The application of this chapter shall not limit the City's legal
rights under other chapters, the Ohio Revised Code or the common law.
(Ord. 09-2017.  Passed 6-1-17.)
1802.08  PAYMENTS AND COLLECTIONS.
   Unassessed charges for abatement, fines and penalties shall be paid to the
City Department of Finance. Charges for abatement, fines and penalties that
have been certified to the Butler County Treasurer's Office for collection may
be paid to the City Department of Finance or the Butler County Treasurer's
Office.
(Ord. 09-2017.  Passed 6-1-17.)
